text.p: Here are the highlights of stories in the Danish press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
--BG Bank has paid 600,000 crowns to a disatisfied customer who claims to have been wrongly advised in the 1990 purchase of shares in now-defunct Commercial Holdings.
--Tax minister Carsten Koch is considering reducing VAT on services most threatened by VAT-free competition on the internet, such as information, know-how and entertainment products.
--Denmark's leadership of a U.N. Human Rights Commission motion against China could hurt Danish drug company Novo Nordisk, which has invested 1.4 billion crowns in a Chinese factory.

--Danish heating suppliers are challenging the DONG consortium's exclusive right to use the national gas grid to supply gas and are investigating the possibility of importing foreign gas at cheaper prices than DONG's North Sea product.
--Growing resistance within mortage lender Nykredit to a merger with BG Bank makes a marriage unlikely but a flotation of Nykredit is still on the cards.
--The Copenhagen and Stockholm stock exchanges are close to signing a letter of intent to collaborate on trading systems.
